Claude Code EAP Report

Opus 4.5 vs Opus 4.6: Behavioral Patterns in Practice

An exploratory single-user case study across 2,320 tasks—observational findings, not controlled comparison
Samuel H. Christie V · February 2026 · Claude Code Early Access Program

1. Executive Summary

Per-Task Cost
−10 to −35%
4.6 cheaper trivial through moderate
Output Token Ratio
2.3×
4.6: 2,243 avg vs 4.5: 953 avg
Tool Calls / Task
+57%
4.6: 16.3 avg vs 4.5: 10.4 avg
Bonferroni Survivors
9 / 115
Tool calls, tools/file, alignment, duration, failed rate, 4 distributions
Study design note: This is a single-user observational study with non-random task assignment. Opus 4.5 data spans 2 months across 30 projects (1,729 tasks); Opus 4.6 spans 8 days across 14 projects (591 tasks). Differences may reflect the user, project mix, or time period rather than model capabilities. All findings should be treated as hypotheses for future testing.

Observed patterns suggest the two models work differently at comparable success rates. Opus 4.6 uses 57% more tool calls, deploys subagents that are 74% read-only Explore agents, and plans 8× more often. Of 115 statistical tests with Bonferroni correction, nine survive—mostly about how each model works (tool usage, distributions), not whether they succeed. Several initial findings were reversed during analysis when more direct signals became available (§9).

The observed data is consistent with a pattern where Opus 4.5 acts first and adjusts as needed while Opus 4.6 investigates first and implements in concentrated bursts—but the confounded study design means this characterization is tentative. This report examines where observed patterns diverge, ordered from the strongest signals (cost, tool usage) through behavioral mechanics and quality outcomes.

Contents & Key Findings
  1. Dataset at a Glance463 sessions, 2,320 tasks, 35 projects, $7,411 total cost
  2. Token Economy & Cost4.6 appears 10–35% cheaper at trivial through moderate despite 2.3× more output tokens
  3. Behavioral Patterns4.6 plans 8× more often; 74% of subagents are read-only Explore agents
  4. Quality & SatisfactionAlignment score and failed rate survive Bonferroni; 4.6 fails less often (8.5% vs 14.1%)
  5. Edit Accuracy4.6 rewrites 10.3% of edits vs 16.6% for 4.5
  6. Complexity & Resource UsageTool usage gap is the strongest statistical signal (p<0.000003)
  7. Model ProfilesObserved behavioral patterns (not routing recommendations)
  8. Future InvestigationsPlanning, session dynamics, compaction—data ready, causal analysis pending
  9. MethodologyPipeline, development process, and limitations

1. Dataset at a Glance

Sessions Analyzed
463
327 (4.5) + 136 (4.6)
Tasks Extracted
2,320
1,729 (4.5) + 591 (4.6)
Projects Spanned
35
9 shared between both models
Total API Cost
$7,411
$5,292 (4.5) + $2,119 (4.6)

All data comes from a single user's organic Claude Code sessions between December 2025 and February 2026. The dataset is intentionally asymmetric: Opus 4.5 served as the primary model for two months, while Opus 4.6 entered evaluation in early February. This means Opus 4.5 totals are larger in absolute terms, but per-task and per-session comparisons normalize for this. Where sample size limits statistical power, the report notes it explicitly.

Per-model composition

The dataset reflects organic usage patterns, not a controlled experiment. Opus 4.5 accumulated sessions over two months of daily use; Opus 4.6 entered evaluation in early February 2026.

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6 Combined
Sessions 327 136 463
Tasks 1,729 591 2,320
Tasks / session 5.3 4.3 5.0
Projects 30 14 35
Date range Dec 5 – Feb 10 Feb 3 – Feb 11 Dec 5 – Feb 11
User messages 20,538 10,712 31,250
Tool calls 18,002 9,658 27,660

The 2:1 session ratio means per-task averages for Opus 4.5 are more robust, while Opus 4.6 estimates carry wider confidence intervals. Opus 4.6 sessions are concentrated across 14 projects (all of which also have Opus 4.5 sessions), providing natural overlap for matched-pair comparisons where they apply.

By complexity

Complexity is inferred from tool count, files touched, and lines changed. Over half of all tasks are trivial (single-turn interactions), while major tasks (>50 tool calls or >500 lines) represent ~1% of volume but a significant share of cost.

The task type distributions are broadly similar across models, suggesting the user's work patterns remained consistent. The complexity mix is also comparable, though Opus 4.6 has a slightly higher share of moderate-and-above tasks (42.1% vs 33.3%), likely reflecting the evaluation period's focus on substantive work rather than quick queries.

Token volumes and code output

Raw token volumes across the full dataset. These are absolute totals, not per-task averages (see §2 for normalized comparisons).

Output composition

Model output splits into thinking (extended thinking / chain-of-thought, not billed as output) and text (visible response, code, tool calls). Estimated from character counts with a 3:1 chars-to-tokens ratio for thinking.

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6
Est. thinking tokens 1,419,559 656,741
Est. text tokens 674,821 347,835
Thinking ratio (tasks using thinking) 75.1% 58.5%
Avg requests / task 7.5 9.6

Code output

Metric Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6 Combined
Files touched 2,893 1,549 4,442
Lines added 178,794 64,673 243,467
Lines removed 37,493 18,186 55,679

Cache reads dominate the token budget: 91% of all tokens processed were served from cache rather than freshly encoded. This reflects Claude Code's prompt architecture, where the system prompt and conversation history are re-sent with each API call but largely hit the prompt cache.

2. Token Economy & Cost

Extracting API usage data from session logs reveals how each model allocates its computational budget. Despite producing more output tokens and making more API round-trips (9.6 vs 7.5 requests/task), Opus 4.6 shows lower per-task costs at trivial through moderate levels, likely reflecting higher cache hit rates from concentrated project usage during the shorter 4.6 evaluation period.

Per-Task Cost
~$2.55
$2.46 (4.5) vs $2.63 (4.6)
Output Token Ratio
2.3×
4.6 produces 2,243 vs 953 avg tokens
Thinking Depth Gap
+58%
4,175 vs 2,635 chars when thinking

Thinking Calibration

Opus 4.5 thinks more often (75% of tasks) but shallowly. Opus 4.6 thinks less often (58%) but more deeply when it does. The pattern reverses at the complexity extremes:

Thinking calibration: Opus 4.6 shows better calibration of when thinking is needed. It skips thinking for 57% of trivial tasks (vs 23% for Opus 4.5), but engages thinking for 90% of moderate tasks (vs 89%). Opus 4.5 over-thinks easy problems; at moderate complexity, 4.6 shows slightly higher thinking engagement.

The 4.3× ratio for refactoring is notable: Opus 4.6 produces substantially more output tokens for refactoring tasks, suggesting more thorough changes. For continuation tasks (follow-ups within a session), Opus 4.6 produces 1.8× the output volume of Opus 4.5.

Cost by Complexity

ComplexityCost Comparison4.5 avg cost4.6 avg costΔ

 $3.52$3.19−9%

B
$7.32
 $7.25$7.32+1%
Major
A
$12.51
B
$16.18
 $12.51$16.18+29%

Normalizing by session hours rather than task count reinforces the per-task finding: Opus 4.5 costs $12.75/session-hour ($5,292 over 415.2h) vs $6.81/session-hour for Opus 4.6 ($2,074 over 304.5h)—a 47% reduction. Session hours measure wall-clock time from first to last message, so this metric includes idle time and is not a direct measure of active coding cost. Still, it confirms the per-task cost advantage extends to session-level efficiency.

Counter-intuitive cost finding (with caveats): Despite producing more output tokens, Opus 4.6 appears 10–35% cheaper per task from trivial through moderate levels, likely from more efficient prompt caching. The exception is major tasks, where 4.6 costs +29% more—but this is based on 18 4.6 major tasks vs 19 for 4.5, so the estimate is unreliable. These figures come from organic sessions where task mix, session structure, and user behavior differ between models. Without more controlled experiments, per-complexity cost advantages should be interpreted cautiously—some of the gap may reflect differences in how the models were used rather than inherent efficiency.
Cache Efficiency by Complexity

Thinking tokens are billed as output but do not enter the conversation history or affect cache behavior. Visible text output accumulates in history and increases subsequent input size. Cache writes ($18.75/MTok) are 12.5× more expensive than cache reads ($1.50/MTok).

Token breakdown by complexity level

Per-task average token usage driving the cost differences. Opus 4.6 produces more output but uses less fresh input, relying more on cached context:

Complexity 4.5 output/task 4.6 output/task 4.5 thinking chars 4.6 thinking chars 4.5 input/task 4.6 input/task 4.5 requests 4.6 requests
Trivial 97 184 864 811 14 15 1.6 1.8
Simple 514 761 1,717 1,551 137 159 5.7 5.3
Moderate 1,506 2,571 3,775 3,974 601 267 11.4 11.8
Complex 3,903 9,416 7,257 9,150 1,484 490 26.3 29.7
Major 8,465 15,971 11,747 7,199 2,020 477 52.4 66.3

At complex tasks, Opus 4.6 uses fewer fresh input tokens per task (490 vs 1,484) while producing 141% more output (9,416 vs 3,903). Despite using similar request counts per task at the complex level (29.7 vs 26.3), Opus 4.6 achieves much more effective cache utilization, and the output cost premium is offset by input savings.

Caveat: These averages come from organic sessions with different task mixes per model. Some of the per-complexity gap may reflect session-level factors (e.g., caching benefits accumulate within longer sessions).

Subagent strategies diverge: Both models deploy similar total subagents (283 vs 262) but they serve different purposes. For Opus 4.6, 74% are lightweight, read-only Explore agents that gather context before implementation begins, with 15% general-purpose. Opus 4.5 splits its subagents more evenly—47% Explore, 37% general-purpose implementation workers that visibly modify files. Both front-load research, but Opus 4.6 concentrates even more heavily on read-only exploration.
Significance: Autonomy level (p<0.001, V=0.15) survives Bonferroni correction (threshold p<0.00043). One-shot rate is not significant (p=0.20).

4. Quality & Satisfaction

Failed Rate
8.5% vs 14.1%
4.6 fails less often (p=0.000)
Alignment Score
d=-0.24
4.6 higher (p=0.000001, Bonferroni)
Bonferroni Survivors
5 / 9
alignment, failed rate, completion, iteration, communication

LLM-annotated alignment scores (1–5 scale) show Opus 4.6 scoring higher on average, an effect that survives Bonferroni correction (p=0.000001, d=-0.24). The failed rate difference is also significant: 8.5% of 4.6 tasks fail vs 14.1% for 4.5 (p=0.000). Three categorical distributions—task completion, iteration required, and communication quality—also survive Bonferroni, indicating the models differ in how they reach outcomes, not just in outcome rates.

 ≈ Tie
Quality confound: Opus 4.6’s different complexity mix (42% moderate-and-above vs 33% for 4.5) means it tackles harder work on average. Despite this, it achieves higher alignment scores and a lower failure rate—suggesting genuine capability improvement, though task selection remains confounded.

Bonferroni Correction

With 9 independent tests conducted (1 Mann-Whitney U, 7 proportion tests, 1 chi-square), the Bonferroni-corrected significance threshold is = 0.05 / 9 = 0.0056.

Tests surviving Bonferroni correction (p < 0.0056):

  • Alignment score: p = 0.000001 (significant)
  • Failed Rate: p = 0.000409 (significant)
  • Task completion distribution: p = 0.000003 (significant)

Tests significant at = 0.05 but not after correction:

  • Satisfaction Rate: p = 0.0178 (marginal)
  • Complete Rate: p = 0.0046 (marginal)
  • Scope Expanded Rate: p = 0.0122 (marginal)

Non-significant tests:

  • Dissatisfaction Rate: p = 0.529 (both models 0%)
  • One Shot Rate: p = 0.215
  • Good Execution Rate: p = 0.673

5. Edit Accuracy

Rewrite Rate
10.3% vs 16.6%
4.6 rewrites less of its own output
Editing Tasks
946
700 (4.5) + 246 (4.6)
Overlapping Edits
407 / 120
Self-corrections, error recovery, user-directed, iterative

Edit timeline analysis tracks every Edit and Write tool call, building per-file content ownership maps to detect when a model later overwrites its own earlier output. Opus 4.5 rewrites 16.6% of its edits vs 10.3% for Opus 4.6—a gap that has widened as the dataset grew. Overlap classification reveals the rewrites are predominantly iterative refinement (63% for 4.5, largest category), not error recovery.

Interpretation: A lower rewrite rate is consistent with Opus 4.6’s research-first approach—investigating before editing reduces the need for later corrections. However, some rework reflects healthy iteration rather than mistakes; the distinction between “self-correction” and “iterative refinement” is heuristic-based.

Opus 4.6 sessions skew toward higher complexity: fewer trivial tasks (36% vs 47%) and proportionally more moderate tasks (27% vs 21%). This makes raw aggregate comparisons misleading—Opus 4.6 is tackling harder work on average.

Significance: Tool calls/task (p<0.000001, d=−0.29) and tools/file (p<0.000001, d=−0.10) survive Bonferroni correction—among the strongest signals in the study. Lines/minute is not significant (p=0.94).
The exploration–output tradeoff: Opus 4.6 uses 57% more tool calls per task yet produces only 6% more lines of code per task. The extra activity is predominantly research, not proportional output growth. Alignment scores are significantly higher for 4.6 (d=−0.24, p=0.000001), surviving Bonferroni correction, though this may partly reflect the different task mix.

7. Model Profiles

Opus 4.5 — Observed Pattern

Observed approach: Tends to act first and adjust as needed. Jumps to implementation with minimal upfront research.

Subagents: 47% Explore, 37% general-purpose (implementation workers). Primarily autonomous (54%).

Planning: Rarely uses planning mode (1.7%). Distributes research evenly through the task.

Observed strengths: Efficient on trivial and simple tasks. Lower tool overhead. Stable performance across session lengths.

Observed weaknesses: Higher rewrite rate (16.6%). More tool calls go to implementation vs research.

Opus 4.6 — Observed Pattern

Observed approach: Tends to research first, then implement in focused bursts. Front-loads investigation before touching files.

Subagents: 74% Explore (read-only research), 15% general-purpose. More autonomous (84%).

Planning: Uses planning mode more often (13.9% of tasks, 82 of 591).

Observed strengths: Lower rewrite rate (10.3%). Lower cost at trivial–moderate complexity.

Observed weaknesses: Higher tool overhead (58% more calls). Costlier at major complexity (n=18).

Observed Patterns by Task Type

Caveat: These patterns are observational, from a single user with non-random task assignment. They should be treated as hypotheses for controlled testing, not as routing recommendations.

Task TypeObserved PatternEvidence & Caveats
Trivial / simple tasksSimilar outcomes4.6 appears 29–35% cheaper; comparable completion rates
Complex / major tasks4.6 showed higher alignmentModerate sample (n=92 complex+major for 4.6); confounded by project differences
Refactoring4.6 produced 4.3× outputSuggests more thorough changes; lower rewrite rate (§5)
Investigation / research4.6 used more Explore agents74% read-only subagents; consistent with research-first pattern
Long sessions (9+ tasks)Both show some degradation4.6 may degrade faster but still scored higher; small sample for late-session tasks
Parallel execution4.6 backgrounded more tasks4.5 spawned more agents but ran them sequentially

8. Future Investigations

The following areas show suggestive patterns but need deeper analysis before drawing conclusions. The data thresholds are met; what remains is causal or structural analysis that the current pipeline cannot automate. Run scripts/check_readiness.py --dir comparisons/opus-4.5-vs-4.6 to check current status.

Planning

Opus 4.6 enters plan mode on 13.9% of tasks (82 of 591) vs 1.7% for Opus 4.5. Adoption scales steeply with complexity: 51.4% at complex, 72.2% at major. Planned tasks show a modest alignment benefit (+0.18 overall) that reverses at complex and major tiers, suggesting planning helps most at moderate complexity.

Next step: Planning is not randomly assigned—the model selects when to plan. Propensity-score matching or complexity-controlled analysis would help separate planning efficacy from task selection bias.

Session Dynamics

Task duration survives Bonferroni correction (p=0.000001). Opus 4.6 takes longer per task (median 129.6s vs 94.0s), with the explore phase running 2.2× longer at median (67.8s vs 31.3s). Effort distribution shows 4.6 allocates more tool calls to research (35.1% vs 28.3%) and fewer to implementation (17.5% vs 27.0%). Active-time cost is $24.66/hour for 4.6 vs $20.96/hour for 4.5 (5-min idle threshold).

Next step: Session overlap analysis (1,765 overlapping pairs, max concurrency 11) complicates per-session cost attribution. Active-time cost varies with idle threshold (see sensitivity table above), but the directional relationship is stable across all thresholds tested.

Compaction

Context-window compaction occurs in 10.1% of 4.5 sessions (33/327) and 12.5% of 4.6 sessions (17/136). Pre/post comparisons show improvement after compaction, but a position-adjusted control group reveals the effect is driven by session position, not compaction itself (position-adjusted effect: −0.13 for 4.5, −0.23 for 4.6).

Next step: Compaction appears to preserve rather than degrade performance. The slightly negative position-adjusted effect for 4.6 warrants monitoring. Pre/post outcome analysis on task completion and satisfaction (not just alignment) may reveal effects masked by single-metric analysis.

9. Methodology

Data Cleaning Methodology

Task-level data cleaning applied four exclusion rules and four informational flags to canonical tasks before analysis. Exclusions remove tasks that do not represent genuine user-model interactions; flags annotate tasks with contextual metadata without removing them.

Exclusion Rules

RuleDescriptionOpus 4.5Opus 4.6
slash_commandTask prompt is a slash command (/command) or <command-name> tag — these invoke built-in features, not model reasoning——
system_continuationAutomatic continuations triggered by the system (e.g., context compaction boundaries, session resumptions) rather than deliberate user prompts——
empty_continuationBare acknowledgement prompts ("continue", "ok", "yes") with zero tool calls and <5s duration — the model produced no meaningful work——
no_response_interruptTasks where the model produced zero output (0 tool calls, 0 duration) before the session ended, typically user cancellations——

Informational Flags

These flags are preserved on included tasks for subgroup analysis but do not trigger exclusion:

  • meta — Task occurred within a meta-analysis session (e.g., this report's own development), where the model analyzed its own output
  • no_project — No project directory was associated with the session
  • interrupted — User interrupted the model mid-response (based on session end pattern)
  • post_compaction — Task occurred after a context compaction event in the same session, potentially with degraded context

Project Overlap & Sensitivity Analysis

A potential confound arises from unequal project coverage between models. To quantify this, a sensitivity analysis compares all statistical tests on the full dataset against a restricted subset containing only tasks from projects where both models were active. If results agree across both analyses, the project confound is unlikely to explain observed differences.

Each Claude Code session was segmented into tasks based on user-message boundaries and topic shifts. An LLM annotator classified each task for complexity, type, sentiment, completion status, and alignment score (1–5 scale). Behavioral metrics—subagent usage, planning, parallelization—were extracted from tool-call logs.

Edit timeline analysis tracked 4,799 Edit/Write tool calls across all sessions, building per-file content ownership maps to detect when a later edit’s old_string overlaps with an earlier edit’s new_string. Overlaps are detected via three tiers (exact match, containment at ≥30% ratio, and Jaccard line overlap) and classified by context (self-correction, error recovery, user-directed, iterative refinement). Edit metrics were joined with task classifications to compute complexity-binned accuracy rates (93% and 88% coverage for the two models).

Compaction analysis found 79 compact_boundary system messages across 50 compacting sessions, extracting trigger type, pre-compaction token count, and position. Outcome impact was measured by splitting tasks into pre/post groups at the first compaction timestamp, with a control group of non-compacting sessions split at the median compaction position to isolate position effects.

Statistical testing: 115 tests were conducted: chi-square (categorical), Mann-Whitney U (continuous), proportion tests (rates). Bonferroni-corrected threshold: p<0.00043. Nine findings survive correction: alignment score (p=0.000001), duration (p=0.000001), tool calls/task (p<0.000001), tools/file (p<0.000001), failed rate (p=0.00041), and four categorical distributions (task completion, iteration required, communication quality, autonomy level). Significance notes appear inline in each section.

Development Process

This analysis was developed iteratively. Several approaches were tried and abandoned when they proved unreliable:

Automated dissatisfaction detection (abandoned as primary signal): Initial LLM-based sentiment classification flagged 7–9% dissatisfaction for both models. LLM-agent audit of all 59 flagged cases revealed 73–93% false positive rates—the classifiers were fooled by task-coordination language (e.g., “fix” in subagent prompts). This approach was replaced by edit timeline analysis, which detects self-corrections mechanistically rather than through sentiment proxies.

LLM quality judgement (dropped): An LLM judge was asked to compare code quality between models. The results were unreliable—the judge lacked sufficient context to evaluate whether code met domain requirements, and produced confident but ungrounded assessments. This section was removed entirely rather than presented with caveats.

Refactoring routing recommendation (revised): Early signals suggested Opus 4.5 was better for refactoring, based on four false-positive dissatisfaction flags and small sample sizes. Sentiment detection and git retention both proved unreliable. Edit timeline analysis provided a more direct mechanistic signal: tracking every edit across all sessions revealed Opus 4.5 with a 16.6% rewrite rate vs 10.3% for Opus 4.6, a gap that has widened as the Opus 4.6 sample has grown (now 246 editing tasks, 120 overlapping edits).

Limitations

Single user: All data comes from one developer’s workflow. Results may not generalize to other users, codebases, or task distributions.

Observational, not experimental: Tasks were not randomly assigned to models. Opus 4.6 was used later chronologically and on different (often harder) tasks, confounding model effects with task effects.

Complexity confound: Opus 4.6’s different complexity mix (42% moderate-and-above vs 33% for Opus 4.5) inflates its resource usage metrics and may suppress its satisfaction scores relative to what it would achieve on equivalent tasks.

Sample asymmetry: The 2.9:1 ratio (1,729 vs 591 tasks) means Opus 4.5 estimates have narrower confidence intervals. Effect sizes for Opus 4.6 are less precise.

LLM-in-the-loop analysis: All task classification, sentiment analysis, and dissatisfaction auditing was performed by LLM agents (Claude Haiku and Sonnet), with human review of outputs and skepticism-driven re-auditing. No classification was done by hand.

Claude Code Early Access Program · Single-user exploratory case study · February 2026
